content.raw: @keflavich do you have any thoughts on this PR?
content.html: adam ginsburg do you have any thoughts on this PR?

pullrequest.title: Removing line database stuff from the FITS frontend

content.raw: It looks fine, but I am not sure I understand entirely yet.  Is it really necessary to write the new cubes to disk?  The big advantage of `SpectralCube` is that it is very cheap and easy to make new slabs (with new centers) without ever duplicating the data in memory or on disk.  What you have is useful, but it would be useful to also have direct access to in-memory cubes.
content.html: It looks fine, but I am not sure I understand entirely yet. Is it really necessary to write the new cubes to disk? The big advantage of SpectralCube is that it is very cheap and easy to make new slabs (with new centers) without ever duplicating the data in memory or on disk. What you have is useful, but it would be useful to also have direct access to in-memory cubes.

pullrequest.title: Removing line database stuff from the FITS frontend

content.raw:
We don't have to write it to disk, no. But the idea is to create something that yt can load up as a dataset, and we want something where the different slabs become different yt fields on the _same_ grid, where everything is rescaled to a new spectral axis where the center is the origin. This is what the yt class `FITSImageBuffer` is used for in this case. Now, we can create a `FITSImageBuffer` instance in memory, and create a dataset instance out of it in yt, without having to write it to disk. But I think that the use case here goes beyond a little what `SpectralCube` is trying to do, and is more yt-centric (otherwise I would probably have implemented this in `SpectralCube`).

The only question, then, is if in the process of making the `FITSImageBuffer` instance it becomes necessary to copy data.
content.html:
We don't have to write it to disk, no. But the idea is to create something that yt can load up as a dataset, and we want something where the different slabs become different yt fields on the same grid, where everything is rescaled to a new spectral axis where the center is the origin. This is what the yt class FITSImageBuffer is used for in this case. Now, we can create a FITSImageBuffer instance in memory, and create a dataset instance out of it in yt, without having to write it to disk. But I think that the use case here goes beyond a little what SpectralCube is trying to do, and is more yt-centric (otherwise I would probably have implemented this in SpectralCube).

The only question, then, is if in the process of making the FITSImageBuffer instance it becomes necessary to copy data.

pullrequest.title: Removing line database stuff from the FITS frontend

content.raw: You're getting a copy of the `SpectralCube` object, but not the underlying data.  You'd need to use `subcube.filled_data[:,:,:]` to load it into memory.  I'm not sure which question you're asking
content.html: You're getting a copy of the SpectralCube object, but not the underlying data. You'd need to use subcube.filled_data[:,:,:] to load it into memory. I'm not sure which question you're asking

pullrequest.title: Removing line database stuff from the FITS frontend

content.raw: What I'd like to do is get a NumPy array corresponding to the 3D array of the subcube's data without creating a copy, if that is possible.
content.html: What I'd like to do is get a NumPy array corresponding to the 3D array of the subcube's data without creating a copy, if that is possible.

pullrequest.title: Removing line database stuff from the FITS frontend

content.raw: `filled_data[:]` will do that: no copy, but it will force loading the data into memory (if it was memmap'd before)
content.html: filled_data[:] will do that: no copy, but it will force loading the data into memory (if it was memmap'd before)

pullrequest.title: Removing line database stuff from the FITS frontend

content.raw: Good point. For me, I think the benefit is that you get a yt dataset as output, with all of these lines re-gridded to the same domain as fields. I think the "multiple fields at once" aspect of it is the strength that yt offers.
content.html: Good point. For me, I think the benefit is that you get a yt dataset as output, with all of these lines re-gridded to the same domain as fields. I think the "multiple fields at once" aspect of it is the strength that yt offers.

pullrequest.title: Removing line database stuff from the FITS frontend

content.raw:
A couple of examples are:

* If you wanted to make a phase plot of one line versus another
* If you wanted to plot rays of the lines against each other at a given spatial location

@samskillman showed some of these in a notebook at the NRAO meeting--I'll have to dig that up again and put it in the docs.
content.html:
A couple of examples are:

  • If you wanted to make a phase plot of one line versus another
  • If you wanted to plot rays of the lines against each other at a given spatial location

Sam Skillman showed some of these in a notebook at the NRAO meeting--I'll have to dig that up again and put it in the docs.

content.html: That notebook does work with the new way of doing it as well.

pullrequest.title: Removing line database stuff from the FITS frontend

description:
When we developed the FITS frontend at NRAO, @samskillman included some code which allowed one to take line data from a spectral cube FITS file and implement the different lines as a series of fields, if the user provided a database of line names, locations, and widths. 

While this was a great demonstration of yt's capabilties, the logic that is required to make it work makes the FITS frontend a lot more complicated than it already is, especially in `FITSIOHandler`. I also think it's too specific a use case to be part of the frontend itself.

The purpose of this PR is to strip this logic out of the FITS frontend, in favor of re-implementing it at a later date as some kind of plugin. It's not clear to me that it's being used by anyone. Removing it makes what is going on with the FITS frontend more comprehensible. 

UPDATE:

I've reimplemented this functionality in a new function, `create_spectral_slabs`. It uses the [spectral-cube](http://spectral-cube.readthedocs.org) package to create the fields. It writes a new FITS file which contains the different spectral slabs in different FITS images, in a format that yt readily understands. I also added info about this function to the docs (we did not document the previous functionality at all).

@MatthewTurk I think that generalizing this to non-FITS-based data is straightforward when the time comes, and we won't have to change this much in order to do so. 

UPDATE 2: This now returns a `FITSDataset` instance directly instead of writing a file, which was a good suggestion from @keflavich.
